The trolleybus starts from a place where the voice of war has been gathered. The grand monument “Motherland” raises her sword - as a symbol of defense, not attack. In this museum - not just the history of the front, but human destinies, letters from the trenches, and the tears of victories and losses. And now the trolleybus turns toward a place that rings with bronze bells. Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra - not just a monastery. Its a thousand years of spirituality, underground caves with holy relics, ancient frescoes, and domes that gleam in the sun just as they did a hundred years ago. From the window, you can see the domes of the Near and Far Caves, the Lavra walls, and even the modern bell tower - a mirror of the sky.
Station - Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. If youre getting off - listen not only to the bells. Listen to the silence. Sometimes it speaks louder. From the spiritual heart, we move to a place where memory is painful - but sacred. On the hill where the Holodomor Memorial stands - silence. Not because nothing happens here. But because there are no words that can describe what happened in 1932–1933. You pass by the Church of the Savior on Berestovo - one of the oldest in Kyiv, where princes once prayed. And beside it - a modern white memorial shaped like a candle. A candle for the millions tortured by hunger, surrounded by silence, indifference, and fear.
Station - Holodomor Victims Memorial. If youre getting off - stop for a moment. Because memory of hunger has no expiration date. And now - from one candle of memory to another. Because the Park of Eternal Glory is a place where people walk every day, carrying flowers, memories, and gratitude. Even without monuments, this park breathes with peace. Everything here seems to say: life goes on. And memory - too. At the top stands the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, the obelisk, and the panorama of the Dnipro, where time itself seems to pause. You can ride past - but its better to return on foot. This place deserves silence.
Station - Park of Eternal Glory. If youre getting off - dont hurry. These trees have seen more than we can imagine. A short but powerful stop - Glory Square. This is no longer only about war. Its a meeting place, a crossroads, a space between past and future. People stop here for different reasons: some to remember, some just to cross the street. But the name speaks for itself: Glory isnt about loud fanfares. Its about daily remembrance.
Station - Glory Square. If youre getting off - remember: glory isnt only victory. Its the ability not to forget those who never returned. And finally - the end of the route. Station - Arsenalna. The deepest metro station in the world, and yet the closest to the essence of history. Right here - the Arsenal, where revolutions once began. Here - hills that witnessed Kyivan Rus and the Maidans. And right here, in the whirl of history, your journey on trolleybus No. 38 comes to an end. But, just like in Kyiv, no stop is truly final. Each one is simply a new perspective.
Station - Arsenalna Metro. If youre getting off - look around. Beneath these hills lies not only the metro, but countless buried choices, pains, and hopes. And now - a few minutes past one of the most iconic sites of Soviet Kyiv - the Arsenal Factory. Once, artillery was forged here. Real, iron, and heavy. Later - optics, instruments for space exploration. And earlier still - in 1918, the Arsenal workers uprising took place here. It was brutally suppressed. But from that revolt came the name that still lives - Arsenalna. Today, “Arsenal” is a space of transformation. Some workshops have already turned into galleries, startups, creative hubs. Old factories - with new meaning.
Station - Arsenal Factory. If youre getting off - look at the bricks. They have outlived empires and now breathe freely - just like we do. And we move on. Here in this Administrative Services Center - people register addresses, change surnames, get certificates, documents… It might seem routine. But behind every “window No. 5” - a small life story. A marriage. A divorce. The birth of a child. The loss of a loved one. Every application is about a person - even if its typed in a cold font.
Station - Pechersk District Administrative Services Center. If youre getting off - remember: even in a queue, you can feel that youre part of a city that works. The trolleybus departs from the epicenter of bureaucratic Kyiv - the ASC. But even here, among certificates and e-queues, lives a city that quietly solves hundreds of small human stories every day. Ahead - Kopylenko Street, named after Oleksandr Kopylenko - a Ukrainian writer, publicist, and childrens author. It may seem theres a gap between the bureaucracy of forms and the warmth of literature - but maybe thats exactly what makes a city real.
Station - Kopylenko Street. If youre getting off - remember: even next to offices, there can live stories worthy of books. The next station sounds strict: General Almazov. Thats Ivan Almazov - Major General of the Medical Service, who made his mark in military medicine. And yes - this is about saving lives, not taking them. The street passes hospitals, administrative buildings, and the old quarters of Pechersk. Here, Kyiv is calm, serious, and responsible.
Station - General Almazov Street. If youre getting off - remember: military uniforms may differ, but dignity is always the same. We move toward one of Kyivs oldest names. Arsenalna - a word born of explosions in history, real weapons, and symbolic battles. Nearby stands the old Kyiv Fortress, the Arsenal Museum, and the places where the fate of the capital was decided more than once. The story of the Arsenal is a story of uprisings, resistance, and courage.
Station - Arsenalna Street. If youre getting off - dont forget: Kyiv remembers every shot. And every word of defiance. And now - from the history of struggle to the history of spirit. Lesya Ukrainka Square is not just about a woman-poet. Its about unbreakable strength, love for words, for Ukraine, and for life - even when it hurts. Here, among modern towers and offices, we honor that inner front Lesya Kosach carried all her life.
Station - Lesya Ukrainka Square. If youre getting off - remember: a frail body does not mean a weak voice. Kyiv knows that well. This station is mysterious. The Round Tower - remains of the Kyiv Fortress - is one of the few that survived. It stands silently, gazing at modern Kyiv as if wondering: “How did you all grow so tall?” Here, Pechersk is stern but beautiful. And if you wander down its side streets, youll still find old houses and fragments of fortress walls.
Station - Round Tower. If youre getting off - look at the stone. It stays silent, but it remembers everything. And finally - a modern name with an American accent. John McCain Street - the new name of what once was Ivan Kudria Street. And in that, theres meaning. McCain was an American senator, a veteran, and a friend of Ukraine who stood firmly against the empire of fear. As you ride down this street, remember not just politics, but solidarity - the value of freedom, and the courage to stand for truth.
Station - John McCain Street. If youre getting off - remember: true allies may not always be near, but theyre always on your side. And now - toward the Pechersk Bridge. It may seem like just infrastructure, but bridges like this are symbols of connection. This bridge links Lesya Ukrainka Boulevard with the Boulevard of Friendship of Nations, flying over the citys ravine and holding Kyiv together. And by the way - if you dare to cross it on foot, youll see one of the most atmospheric views of Pechersk.
Station - Pechersk Bridge. If youre getting off - pause for a moment. Bridges dont just connect cities. They remind us: were strong when we stay together. And here comes Nimanska Street. Short, narrow, with no grand architecture - yet thats its charm. This street feels like the living room of a big apartment block: its where everyday life begins - the kind of life that truly makes up Kyiv. Named after the Neman River - far from here, but the name remains.
Station - Nimanska Street. If youre getting off - dont look for sensations. Sometimes the warmest stories live without bronze or marble. The next stop sounds like a line from a Soviet urban novel: “Optics Shop.” But look closer - places like this hold the citys true memory. This shop has “always” been here. People chose their first glasses here - for their first jobs, first dates, and first school days. The irony? A shop about vision stands in a city that often looks past what matters most. And yet “Optics” reminds us - sometimes, you just need to look a little closer.
Station - Optics Shop. If youre getting off - look carefully. Maybe here, youll see Kyiv a bit differently. And now - a turn ahead. Before you stands the Boychuk Academy of Arts - a place where artists, designers, and dreamers are born. Here youll find paint-scented workshops, creative debates echoing through corridors, and windows glowing at dawn as students finish their projects before defense day. Mykhailo Boychuk, whose name the academy bears, was both a visionary and a tragic figure - a pioneer of Ukrainian monumental art, executed in 1937.
Station - Boychuk Academy of Arts. If youre getting off - remember: not all art hangs in galleries. Almost right after the academy - Dormitory No. 4. Its more than a neighbor; its part of the same living organism. Because art doesnt live in offices - it sleeps in dorms. This building is simple, with typical architecture - but inside, its anything but ordinary. Theres life without polish, but full of inspiration: impromptu exhibitions in hallways, philosophical kitchen talks at 2 a.m., and jam sessions in the bathroom - because the acoustics there are just perfect. A dormitory is a school of survival - and of space.
Station - Dormitory No. 4. If youre getting off - remember: great art often begins in a room for four. Next comes an unexpected shift - from the student world to industrial Kyiv of iron and rails. Zaliznychne Highway - not romantic, but honest. Here, train horns echo, warehouses stand, minibuses weave through - and the city reveals its true, working face. Because even the brightest dreams must arrive on tracks.
Station - Zaliznychne Highway. If youre getting off - dont ignore the noise. It means the city is still alive. And the final station - Vydubychi Metro. But dont think its just a transport hub. The name “Vydubychi” comes from legend. When Prince Volodymyr baptized Kyiv, he threw the pagan idols into the Dnipro River. One of them - Perun - floated back up here. The word “vydybal” means “emerged.” Thats how this place got its name - “where it surfaced.”
Station - Vydubychi Metro. And here our journey ends. For now. Until we meet again.

Our route begins here-at the Vydubychi metro station. This place is steeped in history and bustling with activity. We continue on our way. And here we encounter a new story-Zaliznychne Highway. This is not a grand avenue lined with historic facades, but a lively artery of the city. Trains rumble nearby, trucks drive by, depots and warehouses stand. This part of the route is about the real Kyiv, which works, transports, and repairs. It is about the fact that even the greatest monuments in Pechersk would be impossible without these iron highways. Zaliznychne stop. If you get off, do not ignore the noise: it means that the city is still working and its steel heart is beating. We leave the iron clamor behind and return to a space saturated with youthful energy - Dormitory No. 4. This typical “box” contains a cosmos of creative ideas. It is a place where future designers, artists, and restorers are formed. The dormitory is a survival laboratory where yesterdays coffee is shared with a friend, and the best exhibitions can take place in the corridors. Dormitory No. 4 stop. If you get off here, remember that great creativity often begins in a room for four. Our bus travels a few meters to immerse itself in the very heart of this creativity - the Institute of Mykhailo Boychuk, a brilliant artist and master of his craft. He was the founder of a unique Ukrainian school that combined Byzantine traditions with modernism. Unfortunately, like many talented artists of that time, he fell victim to Stalins repressions and was shot in 1937. Today, the institute is a place of remembrance. Here, they teach not only how to paint, but also how to see meaning.
Boychuk Academy stop. If you get off here, remember: not all art is found in galleries. We continue on our way, and the route takes us to a place with a somewhat ironic name for such a profound city - the Optika store. This stop reminds us of everyday Kyiv, when such stores were symbols of a certain stability and scarcity. “Optika” here is not just a place to buy glasses; it is a point of fixation of memory. It is a micro-history of the city that contrasts with the majestic hills of Pechersk. Optika store station. If you get out, take a closer look: perhaps here you will see Kyiv in a slightly different light, calm and ordinary. And we continue on our way. From the noisy thoroughfare, we turn onto the quiet, almost homely Nymanska Street. It is a short, inconspicuous street that does not appear in tourist guidebooks, but that is what makes it special. It is named after the Neman River, which flows through Lithuania and Belarus, reminding us of geographical connections and the historical wanderings of names. It is a symbol of cozy Pechersk, hidden behind official buildings. Nymanska Street stop. If you get off, do not look for anything sensational: sometimes the warmest stories live without embellishment, right outside the windows. And we are already driving out into the open space, to the technical symbol of communication - the Pechersky Bridge. It would seem to be just a structure built for the convenience of transport. But all bridges have a deeper meaning. This bridge not only connects two points, but also reminds us that a city, like society, is only strong when it sticks together. Pechersky Bridge stop. If you get off, pause for a moment: bridges not only connect cities. They unite societies. We turn onto a street that has been given a new, highly symbolic name - John McCain Street, after the American senator. This is not just a political act, but a tribute to the memory and a sign of gratitude to a man who was an unbreakable friend of Ukraine and consistently opposed Russian imperialism. It is a manifesto of freedom and international solidarity. John McCain Street stop. If you leave, remember that allies are not those who are always around. They are those who always support you. And we are heading to one of the most mysterious objects on our route - the Round Tower. This tower is not an elegant architectural decoration, but a remnant of the Kyiv Fortress, a military facility whose construction began in 1831. It stood and stands silently, simply watching Kyiv transform from a military garrison to a modern capital.
Krugla Bashta stop. If you get off, take a look at the stone: it remembers everything. We are now approaching a large city square dedicated to one of the greatest figures in Ukrainian culture - Lesya Ukrainka Square. This is a space where the indomitable spirit is honored. Larisa Kosach was a poet, playwright, and public figure who became a symbol of the struggle for the Ukrainian idea and language. Her words are the inner front that she held throughout her life. And Kyiv remembers this.
Lesya Ukrainka Square stop. If you get off, remember: a weak body does not mean a weak voice. We are heading to a historically explosive place - Arsenalna Street. This name leads to the old Kyiv fortress, located next to the Arsenal factory, where weapons were manufactured for centuries. This place remembers not only the tsarist cannons, but also the rebel uprising in January 1918. So Arsenalna Street is about determination, the history of popular uprisings, and the fact that this land has never been silent. Arsenalska Street stop. If you get off here, remember that Kyiv remembers every shot fired and every word of resistance. We continue on our way, and our route takes us to another military name - General Almazov Street. Yes, its him, the major general of the medical service who made a significant contribution to military medicine. His name here is a reminder that a military uniform does not always mean weapons and attack. It can mean rescue, treatment, and responsibility for life.
General Almazov Street stop. If you get off, remember: military uniforms may vary, but dignity and compassion are universal. And we make a small but symbolic turn to a person like Oleksandr Kopylenko He is a Ukrainian writer, publicist, and, importantly, author of childrens books. This transition from general to writer is a metaphor for the multifaceted nature of Kyiv. It is in such unexpected combinations that the city lives. Kopylenka Street stop. If you get off, remember: Kyiv is a city where stories for books can live, if you look closely. And our trolleybus arrives at the epicenter of modern Kyiv everyday life - the Administrative Services Center. It is not a monument, but a living institution where hundreds of small human stories are resolved every day: marriage registration, change of surname, child registration, certificates, loss of documents. It is a place where the “cold print” of applications intersects with the hot emotions of life.
Administrative Services Center stop. If you go out, remember: even in a crowd and in a queue, you can feel that you are part of the city. And we move on, discovering new stories. Arsenal Factory. This facility is an era in brick. Built in the 18th century, it was the main artillery base, and in Soviet times it became a well-known manufacturer of optics and space instruments. Today, Arsenal is a space of transformation. These bricks have survived empires and wars, and now live freely, just like us.
Arsenal Factory stop. If you get off, think about it: this place has survived everything and everyone. It has not broken down. And we continue on to a place known throughout the world. Arsenalna metro station. Opened in 1960, it lies at a depth of 105.5 meters. This depth is not only a technical record, it is a metaphor for how deep into history one must descend to understand Kyiv. Nearby are the same Arsenal Hills that have seen princes, revolutions, and Maidans. Here, in the whirlpool of events, many elections, pain, and hopes are buried under these hills.
Arsenalna metro station stop. When you exit, take a look around: beneath these hills lies not only the metro, but also history. We will make a short trip to the famous Square of Glory. The name speaks for itself, but Glory here is not just loud fanfare of victories. It is daily remembrance and the ability not to forget those who did not return. But now it is no longer just about the history of war, but about the crossroads of life. It is a meeting place, an urban hub, a space that lies between the past and the future.
Glory Square stop. If you get off here, remember: glory is not just victory. It is the ability to remember those who did not return. The trolleybus continues on, so we set off on a new adventure. Park of Eternal Glory. This is a place where time seems to stand still. The park was created as a memorial to soldiers who died in World War II. At the top of the hill is the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and an obelisk. Every day, people come here, bringing flowers, memories, and gratitude. But the park is not only about monuments; it is also a symbol that life goes on, and so does memory.
Park of Eternal Glory stop. If you get out, dont rush. These trees have seen more than we can imagine. And we hurry on to a place where memories are painful but sacred - the Holodomor Victims Memorial. Here, on a hill, next to ancient history, stands a modern white memorial in the shape of a candle. This is the Candle of Memory - for the millions who were murdered by starvation. This memorial is silence that speaks louder than any words, because there are no words that could describe the genocide committed by the Soviet authorities. Holodomor Victims Memorial stop. If you go outside, stop for a moment and bow your head. This place deserves to be remembered. And we return to the spiritual heart of Kyiv, a place that echoes with copper bells - the Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. This is not just a monastery - it is a thousand years of spirituality. This historical treasure trove was founded in 1051 by monks Anthony and Theodosius. Here, in the underground caves, the incorruptible relics of saints are kept, and the walls are decorated with ancient frescoes. Look out the window: the golden domes of the Lavra are an eternal symbol of Kyiv, a mirror of the heavens.
Kyiv-Pecherska Lavra stop. If you get off, just stop and admire the view. Our route is gradually coming to an end. The last stop is a place where the voice of war is captured in bronze and stone - near the National Museum of the History of Ukraine in World War II. The majestic monument “Motherland-Mother” raises her sword as a symbol of defense and indestructibility. This is not only the history of the front, but also human destinies: letters from the trenches, personal belongings, tears, victories, and losses.
National Museum of the History of Ukraine in World War II stop. The trolleybus route is over, but yours is still ahead. See you soon!
